title: 114_hr3766
content: The Act is titled the "Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016." It defines "appropriate congressional committees" and "evaluation" for United States foreign assistance programs. The Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 defines covered United States foreign assistance as assistance authorized under specific acts, aimed at making judgments, improving effectiveness, and informing decisions about programming. The Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 defines covered United States foreign assistance as assistance authorized under specific acts to evaluate performance, support innovative programs, and coordinate monitoring and evaluation processes of Federal departments and agencies. The President is required to establish guidelines within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The guidelines established under the Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 aim to provide direction to Federal departments and agencies on monitoring resource use, evaluating outcomes of foreign assistance projects, and applying evaluation findings to project design. The guidelines under the Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 direct Federal departments and agencies on establishing monitoring and evaluation objectives, developing project plans with measurable goals, and applying rigorous methodologies to assess program impact and outcomes. The guidelines for the development and implementation of monitoring and evaluation programs include disseminating guidelines, establishing data collection methodologies, evaluating programs, and conducting impact evaluations on pilot programs. The guidelines include developing a clearinghouse for knowledge sharing, distributing evaluation reports internally, and publicly reporting evaluations within 90 days. The guidelines emphasize the importance of collaborative partnerships, reliable data, and professional evaluation standards for effective monitoring and evaluation of foreign assistance programs. The guidelines stress the use of professional evaluation standards for monitoring and evaluation efforts. The President must submit a detailed report to Congress within 18 months, and the Comptroller General must follow suit after that. The guidelines for monitoring and evaluating covered United States foreign assistance programs are analyzed and assessed by agencies, bureaus, and offices. The Secretary of State is required to update the ForeignAssistance.gov website with comprehensive information on these programs within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of State must receive detailed information on covered United States foreign assistance programs from each Federal department or agency administering such programs. This information will be published on the "ForeignAssistance.gov" website or a successor online publication. The detailed information on covered United States foreign assistance programs must be published on a country or regional basis, including links to strategies, budget documents, justifications, and evaluations. Basic summaries for programs and awards are also required for transparency and accountability. The detailed information on covered United States foreign assistance programs, including obligations, expenditures, and awards, must be published on a country or regional basis within 90 days. Federal departments or agencies administering the programs are not required to provide unrelated information. The head of a Federal department or agency, in consultation with the Secretary of State, may determine that certain information should not be included online if it jeopardizes health, security, or proprietary information. If the Secretary of State believes that including certain information online would harm national interests, they must provide a written determination to congressional committees. The State must provide a written determination to congressional committees regarding the information that should not be made publicly available. If a Federal department or agency fails to comply with this requirement, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a consolidated report to the appropriate congressional committees. The State must provide a written determination to congressional committees regarding information not made publicly available. A consolidated report will be submitted to Congress with detailed explanations and plans for making information public in subsequent years. The online publication requirements include providing information for fiscal years 2015 to the current year and ensuring information availability for future fiscal years. The Sense of Congress is for the Secretary of State and the Administrator of USAID to coordinate data collection and presentation on their respective websites by the end of fiscal year 2018.
